title_sort: harry stafford to walt whitman, 27 july 1878
title: Harry Stafford to Walt Whitman, 27 July 1878
text: Laurel Hills N.J.New JerseyJuly 27th., 78.My Dear, Dear, Friend,I received the rubarbrhubarb to-day, it came just in time: I have been sick for some time past, I took a dose of it as soon as I got it I was when and told on I look I did perhaps were complaining up there.Mr. Whitman, I want to ask don't want at me, it is thisâ€”do you think if I study and write all the spare time I have that in the corse[course] of two or three years I would be able to be an editor? I have been thinking for about two months that I would like to be something, and I that than tryed[tried] to it, my time only of you to think what I have said and tell me what conclusion you have come to whenI see you work to-gather[together] have become settled, and our love sure (although we have had very many rough times to-gather[together]) but we have stuck too[to] each other so far, and we will until we die, I know.I was down to see Friday him, as ined would and I out finding Mother is very sick and has been ever since I came home, she was taken sick that day I was up there. Father is well as usual: he was to market today with potatoes.We are having a fine rain to-night down here, it hasn't come too soon either things were kneeding[needing] will make time so me improve my more.Well I have to close as the paper is given out.Your loving son,H.L. StaffordP.S. write soon and oblige yours. Harry Stafford to Walt Whitman, 27 July 1878
